concern:
Cognitive Psychology Ph.D.   
I'm a 4th year, so you think I'd be used to this! I just have no concept of how much professors have in their discretionary. I'm about to run a study that I've gotten blessing after blessing to run. It's been piloted and I even got a mini $1400 grant for it. Unfortunately, I burned through my money pretty quickly during the pilot/trying different ideas out and I now have to drop another $800+ on my advisor's dime. I'm up against a time pressure and I know I need to just do it, but I can't not think in terms of regular person money and I get so so nervous!! I've resorted to loading smaller amounts of money into Prolific, which generates an annoying number of receipts to be processed.   
Some of the anxiety is because I transferred into this lab in the last year, so I feel like all of my expenses are unplanned expenses. Something that makes me feel better is that my advisor was accepting students this round and ultimately didn't, so that tells me that she was prepared to support another student even after taking me on. She's the head of the department and quite well known, so if there were ever a lab to try out different ideas in, it would be this one. But I'm not on a grant and I don't know where her discretionary money comes from.   
After the failed pilots (which was expensive), she even told me that I need something to work so I can design some follow up studies (clock is ticking), so we might as well "throw money" at the problem. Another explicit blessing.

  
I'm sure I'm not the only one who stresses over this. My friend comes from a very prominent lab and even he books youth hostel lodging and bad flights for conferences out of guilt. Can we all just pump each other up a little here?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you. Please feel free to share anything that's been on your mind or any concerns you may have.
Thanks for having me. I’ve just been really stressed lately about some financial stuff related to my research, and it’s been weighing on me a lot.
That sounds really tough—I can understand why that would be weighing on you. How long has this financial stress related to your research been affecting you, and what parts feel the most overwhelming?

It’s been stressing me out for a few months now, especially since I started running into these unexpected costs. The part that gets me the most is just not knowing how much I’m overstepping or if I’m putting too much pressure on resources that aren’t really mine to use.

Man, I just keep second-guessing every decision I make, you know? Like, I’ve got the green light to move forward, but I can’t shake this feeling that I’m messing up or being a burden. I keep wondering if I should be cutting corners more or if I’m just not thinking things through enough. Have you seen other students deal with this kind of anxiety over stuff like this?

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of uncertainty about your decisions, and that's really weighing on you. It's not uncommon for students to feel this way when they're in situations where they have to make tough decisions about resources and responsibilities. I'm here to listen and support you as we explore these feelings together.

Thanks, I really appreciate that. It’s just nice to know I’m not the only one feeling this way, even if it still sucks to be stuck in my head about it. I guess I’m just trying to figure out how to trust that I’m doing the right thing without constantly worrying I’m screwing up. Like, how do I stop overthinking every little choice when there’s so much on the line?

That's a really valid concern—it's hard to trust yourself when the stakes feel so high. Maybe we can explore some ways to help you develop that trust in your decision-making, even with all the uncertainty. What would that look like for you, if you were able to trust your choices more?

Honestly, if I could trust my choices more, I think I’d feel a lot lighter—like I could just focus on the work instead of stressing over every little thing. It’d be nice to make a decision and not immediately second-guess if it’s gonna blow up in my face or disappoint someone. I don’t know, maybe I’d even sleep better at night without this constant knot in my stomach. How do you think I could start getting to that point?

It's interesting that you bring up feeling lighter and more focused on your work. What if we explored some of your past experiences where you made decisions and things worked out okay, even if they weren't perfect? Maybe there's something to learn from those moments that could help you trust yourself more now.

Yeah, that sounds like a good idea. I mean, I can think of a few times where things turned out fine even when I was freaking out at first, so maybe looking at those could help me chill out a bit. I just don’t know if I can apply that to the stuff I’m dealing with now, since it feels so much bigger. What do you think—how do I connect those past wins to this mess I’m in?

That's a great question. One way to start making that connection could be by reflecting on what specific strengths or strategies you used in those past situations that helped them work out, even when you were worried. For example, did you lean on a particular skill, support system, or mindset that made a difference? If you could identify those elements, they might offer clues about how to approach your current challenges with more confidence.

Honestly, I think I leaned on my ability to problem-solve and just keep pushing through, even when I was anxious, and talking things out with my advisor or peers helped a ton back then. I guess I could try to tap into that same grit and reach out for feedback now, but it’s hard to shake the feeling that this time the stakes are just way higher. How do I convince myself that those old strategies will still work when everything feels so much more intense?

It's understandable to feel like the stakes are higher now, but perhaps reflecting on how those past strategies helped you navigate uncertainty before could offer a sense of reassurance that they might still serve you in this moment. Maybe we can start by identifying one small step you could take, using one of those strengths or strategies, to test the waters and build some confidence?

Yeah, that makes sense. I guess I could start by reaching out to my advisor for a quick check-in on my next move, just to get that reassurance, and treat it like a small test of whether talking it out still helps me feel more grounded. I’m just worried I’ll come off as too needy or unsure, though—how do I balance asking for help without feeling like I’m overdoing it?

That’s a valid concern, and it’s great that you’re thinking about how to approach this in a way that feels authentic to you. One option could be to frame your request as seeking specific feedback on a particular aspect of your work, rather than a general plea for reassurance. This way, you’re coming from a place of proactive problem-solving rather than uncertainty, which might help you feel more confident in reaching out. What do you think about trying that approach for your initial check-in with your advisor?

Yeah, I think that could work. Framing it as asking for specific feedback feels less like I’m just dumping my worries on them, and more like I’m taking charge of the situation, which might help me feel better about reaching out. I’m just still kinda nervous about how often I should be doing this—like, I don’t want to bug them too much. How do I figure out what’s a reasonable amount of check-ins without feeling like I’m overstepping?

That’s a really good point to consider, and I’m glad you’re thinking about finding that balance. How about we brainstorm a rough guideline together, like setting a personal limit on how often you reach out, or checking in only after you’ve made some progress on your own?

Yeah, I like the idea of setting some kind of personal limit so I don’t overthink it or stress about bothering them. Can we maybe figure out what that could look like, like a specific number of times or situations where it feels okay to reach out?

{"reasoning":"The session has covered identifying coping strategies and next steps, such as reaching out for feedback and setting limits on check-ins. The client is more assured about managing anxiety and decision-making.","determination":"stop"}

client: Thanks for having me. I’ve just been really stressed lately about some financial stuff related to my research, and it’s been weighing on me a lot.
